abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The interferon-induced transmembrane-protein 3 (IFITM3) is a vital component of the immune system's defense against viral infection. Variants in the <jats:italic>IFITM3</jats:italic> gene have been linked to changes in expression and the risk of severe Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). This study aimed to investigate whether <jats:italic>IFITM3</jats:italic> rs6598045, quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) cycle threshold (Ct) values, and severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) variants are associated with an increased mortality rate of COVID-19.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The genotyping of <jats:italic>IFITM3</jats:italic> rs6598045 polymorphism was analyzed using the amplification refractory mutation system-polymerase chain reaction in 1342 recovered and 1149 deceased patients positive for SARS-CoV-2.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>In this study, <jats:italic>IFITM3</jats:italic> rs6598045 G allele as minor allele frequency was significantly more common in the deceased patients than in the recovered ones. Furthermore, the highest mortality rates were observed in Delta variant and lowest qPCR Ct values. COVID-19 mortality was associated with <jats:italic>IFITM3</jats:italic> rs6598045 GG and AG in Delta variant and <jats:italic>IFITM3</jats:italic> rs6598045 AG in Alpha variant. A statistically significant difference was observed in the qPCR Ct values between individuals with GG and AG genotypes and those with an AA genotype.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title>
                <jats:p>A possible correlation was observed between the mortality rate of COVID-19, the G allele of <jats:italic>IFITM3</jats:italic> rs6598045, and SARS-CoV-2 variants. However, large-scale research is still required to validate our results.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study was approved by the Ethical Committee of PII (IR.PII.REC.1400.042) and was carried out according to the 1975 Declaration of Helsinki and relevant local regulations. Also, written informed consent was directly obtained from all participants.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

title: Increased risk of COVID-19 mortality rate in IFITM3 rs6598045 G allele carriers infected by SARS-CoV-2 delta variant
